seg.seg: ... separation from (all dear) things [is] finally the end. [25c] ...
... [26a] Sickness, old age, hunger [and] thirst, these [are] the plagues ... [26b]
... (death) is the one who takes (away). [26d] At one [and the same] time ...
... to the Buddha lovingly. [28a] The three (jewels ?) ...
... He died an unbeliever [and] then in a terrible hell he was [re]born. [28] ...
... but another one, an Arhat, threw off (the burden) of the Skandhas ... [29c]
... the emerged (doubts?). [30a] Then (the Buddha) spoke the strophes ...
... they will pass through (the fruit) of merit and hell. [30d] ...
... (without) influence [from the outer world]. [31b] The fruit of the deed never fades, the deed ...
... (The Buddha) was staying in the Jetavana. [32a] In Śrāvastī ...
... (there came to him) death. [33d] The second sat (on the) ground ...
... in a cave of the Sumeru-mountain he sat in meditation [34c] ...
... it came to end for them. All these went to destruction ... [35b]

p.note: Anityavarga (I), part two. Contains strophes 25c-35b in a 4x14 syllable-metre (rhythm: 7/7). From each verse, on average 25 syllables are missing.
The original manuscript is missing, but was a left-over bit of the left-hand side of a leaf with schnurloch. Since is leaf 29 of the manuscript, this leaf must have been number 25.
In II, 8 it is proposed to read the name Kāśa Kausalya and refer to a 3, where the same name (?), unfortunately, is also precisely damaged after ‹kau›.

div.head: Sanskrit parallel
div.p: corresponds to Uv I, 22: sarve kṣayāntā nicayāḥ patanāntāḥ samucchrayāḥ samyogā viprayogāntā maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitam
All accumulations end in ruin; all elevations in fall; unions end in separation, life ends in death.
corresponds to Uv I, 23: sarve sattvā mariṣyanti maraṇāntaṃ hi jīvitam yathā karma gamiṣyanti puṇya pāpa phala upagāḥ
All beings will die; death is the end of life. It is in accordance with their action that they will go, gathering the fruit of merit and fault.
corresponds to Uv I, 24: narakaṃ pāpa karmāṇaḥ kṛta puṇyās tu sad gatim anye tu mārgaṃ bhāvyeha nirvāsyanti nirāsravāḥ
Wrongdoers to hell, men of merit to heaven. But the others, who would have meditated on the (good) path in this world, will go to the Nirvana, freed from impurities.
